items.message:
River levels are forecast to continue to rise at the Tewks. Upper Pound, Mythe, Haw Bridge and Sandhurst river gauges as a result of recent rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected to continue today, 27/12/2021.  Currently no impact is forecast at the Gloucester gauge.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent the River Severn from Tewkesbury to Gloucester. Locations that may be affected include Apperley, Maisemore, and Severn Ham, Tewkesbury may fill. Predicted peaks:- Mythe 3.5m to 3.8m overnight tonight, Haw Bridge 4.4m to 4.6m on 28/12/2021, Sandhurst 2.9m to 3.1m on 28/12/2021.   Further rain showers are forecast over the next 24 hours and we expect river levels to remain elevated in these locations.
  
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking defences.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated by 9am on 28/12/2021, or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high or rising slowly at the Diglis (Worcester), Kempsey Yacht Club and Saxons Lode river gauges as a result of recent rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible today, 27/12/2021.  Flooding may affect low lying land and Roads adjacent the River from Highley to Tewkesbury. Locations that may be affected are Stourport, Holt Fleet, Worcester, Kempsey, Severn Stoke, Upton upon Severn, South Quay, Diglis Parade and the Hylton Road towpath. Flooded drains may affect the racecourse and Worcester County cricket ground. New Street Gate is closed at Upton upon Severn due to flooding and may be impassable. Predicted peaks:- Diglis 2.8m to 3.0m today, Kempsey Yacht Club 5.0m to 5.2m today, Saxons Lode 4.0m to 4.4m today.   
  
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking defences.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated by 9am on 28/12/2021, or as the situation changes.

This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.

River levels have risen at the Lugwardine river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected to continue for the next couple of days. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the River Lugg south of Leominster from Stoke Prior to Mordiford. Other locations that may be affected include Bodenham, Lugwardine and Hampton Bishop. Further rainfall is forecast over the next few days and we expect river levels to remain high. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 09:00 on 28/12/21, or if the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: Sandyford Brook, Ridings Brook, Saredon Brook

items.message:
River levels have risen at the Milford river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible later this afternoon.  Flooding is affecting low-lying land and roads adjacent to the River Sow between Great Bridgeford and Shugborough, the River Penk between Coven and Stafford, the Sandyford Brook, the Rising Brook, the Ridings Brook and the Saredon Brook.   We are issuing this flood alert as a precautionary measure.
Further rainfall is possible over the next 24 hours.  We expect river levels to remain high.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast.  
Please stay aware in case further warnings are issued.  
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 28/12/21, or as the situation changes.

"River levels remain high at the Willington Cableway & Shardlow river gauges as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, the risk of flooding remains.  Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Willington, Barrow upon Trent, Swarkestone, Bargate Lane and the access roads to Willington Meadows, the Twyford Village access road, Church Lane at Barrow, and Ingleby Lane. Current river level at Willington river gauge is 2.77m and at Shardow river gauge is 1.93m.   
Further light rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.  
We are closely monitoring the situation.  
Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 28/12/21, or as the situation changes."

items.message: River levels have risen at the Tern - Walcot river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of property, roads and farmland is expected today, 27/12/2021. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from Wolverley to Newport. Other locations that may be affected include Market Drayton, Wem and Rodington. We expect river levels to remain high for the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and avoid contact with flood water. This message will be updated tomorrow morning 28/12/2021 by 09:00, or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high but largely steady at the Kempsey Yacht Club river gauge as a result of recent rainfall.    Flooding may affect low lying land and Squires walk in the area of the Hatfield Brook Kempsey. Kempsey Flood Alleviation scheme may be operational today, 27/12/2021. Predicted peak:- Kempsey Yacht Club 5.0m to 5.2m today, 27/12/2021. Further rainfall showers are forecast over the next 24 hours and river levels are expected to remain elevated in this location.  
  
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking defences.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.  
This message will be updated by 9am on 28/12/2021, or if the situation changes.

items.message:
River levels remain high but are beginning to fall at the Eathorpe river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, the risk of flooding is reducing.  Flooding is affecting low-lying land and roads adjacent to the River Leam between Grandborough and Leamington including Kites Hardwick, Birdingbury, Marton, Eathorpe, Hunningham and Offchurch and the River Itchen between Southam and Marton including Long Itchington    
  River levels are falling, but still pose a flood risk.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses.  
This message will be updated this evening, 28/12/21, or as the situation changes.

Flooding is affecting low-lying land and roads adjacent to River Avon between Stanford and Rugby, River Swift between Cosford and Rugby and Clay Coton Brook between Yelvertoft and Lilbourne.

items.message: Over the last several days we have seen heavy rainfall in the Middle Nene area. This means that the River Nene and associated tributaries have risen and remain high, which has led to flooding of low lying land and roads close to the river. Further rain is forecast over the next few days and we expect the river to remain high, but our forecasts indicate that flooding to properties isn't likely and therefore flood warnings are not expected to be issued. We are constantly monitoring river levels, and have staff in the field checking for blockages and clearing weedscreens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. Please do not attempt to drive through flood water. This message will be updated in the evening on Monday, 27th December, or as the situation changes.

River levels have fallen at the Cappenham river gauge bur remain high downstream at Newport Pagnell Cemetery river gauge. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is still possible.  We expect flooding to affect River Tove from Towcester to Cosgrove, including Silverstone Brook   
No further rainfall is forecast today.  We expect river levels to remain high for a few days. 
We are closely monitoring the situation.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated this evening, 27/12/21, or as the situation changes.

River levels are high on the Middle River Roding as a result of heavy rainfall. River levels are expected to remain high throughout Monday 27 December and flooding to roads and low lying land, particularly around Loughton and Abridge, is possible. 
We are closely monitoring the situation, checking rivers for blockages and clearing debris from structures.  
Please monitor local water levels and weather conditions. You should avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water and using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.  
This message will be updated this evening, 27/12/21, or as the situation changes

items.message: The risk of flooding from the Upper River Colne has now reduced and levels have fallen below levels of concern. No further flooding to fields and roads is expected, however there may be standing water seen for several days.

  River levels are falling, but still pose a flood risk.

items.description: River Beult from Pluckley and Bethersden to Hampstead Lock at Yalding
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message: This Flood Alert remains in force as river levels remain high and are expected to rise again at Smarden later this afternoon, in response to further rainfall which is forecast on Monday 27 December. Minor flooding could affect low lying land and roads between Smarden and Staplehurst during the day and overnight into Tuesday 28 December. Property flooding is not expected. We are monitoring the situation and our incident response staff are checking defences and structures throughout the area. This message will be updated by 8pm on Monday 27 December, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The Mardyke to the River Thames at Purfleet
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to low lying land, roads and riverside areas is likely from now into tomorrow, Tuesday 28th December 2021. River levels are beginning to drop, but will remain responsive to further rainfall. Areas most at risk are low lying roads and riverside areas along the River Mardyke between North Stifford and Purfleet.  The forecast is for drier conditions today, which will allow river levels to start returning to normal. Take care on riverside footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and will update as necessary. We will update this message by 10am on Tuesday 28th December 2021.

River levels are now returning to normal.The forecast is for a dry day. There is a possibility of a small amount of rain tomorrow afternoon, but totals at the moment are thought to be low.  There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

items.description: River Ray and its tributaries from Shipton Lee to and including Islip

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Ray, Wootten Brook, Doddershall Brook, Tetchwick Brook, Lugershall Brook, Murswell Hill Brook, Cutters Brook, Piddington Brook, Blackthorn Brook, Panshill Brook, Studley Wood Brook, Beckley Brook, Oddington Brook, Gallos Brook, Chipping Farm Stream

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels continue to rise on the lower River Ray following recent rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low-lying land, footpaths and roads is expected to continue, especially in the areas from Lower Arncott to Islip. 
River levels are high and slowly rising. A band of rain is forecast to move through the area this morning, 27/12/21, with the potential to be heavy at times. This will then clear leaving showers this afternoon and overnight.. We expect river levels to continue rising today and levels will  remain high for the next few days at least.
We are closely monitoring the situation. 
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, many of which will be flooded at this point. 
This message will be updated this evening, 27/12/21, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Evenlode from Moreton in Marsh to Cassington and also the River Glyme at Wootton and Woodstock
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels are high on the River Evenlode but have fallen below the flood risk threshold. 
A band of rain is forecast to move through the area this morning, 27/12/21, with the potential to be heavy at times. This will then clear leaving showers this afternoon and overnight. River levels are currently below the flood risk threshold, but may react to further rainfall.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff will be in the area clearing weed/trash screens. 
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 
This message will be updated this evening, 27/12/21, or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high at the Besford Bridge river gauge as a result of recent heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected to continue today, 27/12/2021.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the Brooks from Webheath to Defford. Other locations that may be affected include Crowle, Wickenham, Peopleton, Pinvin and Pershore. Local fords may also be flooded.  Further rainfall showers are forecast over the next 24 hours and we expect river levels to remain elevated in this location. 
  
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking defences and clearing weed screens.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated by 9am on 28/12/2021, or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high at the Evesham and Bredon river gauges as a result of recent rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible today, 27/12/2021.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent the River Avon from Abbotts Salford to Tewkesbury. Other locations that may be affected include Offenham, Evesham, Twyning and the Eckington Road. Predicted peaks:- Evesham has peaked and is currently falling slowly, Bredon 2.2m to 2.4m this morning and into this afternoon, 27/12/2021.  Further rainfall showers are forecast over the next 24 hours and river levels are expected to remain elevated in these locations. 
  
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking defences and clearing weed screens.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.

Flooding of low lying land and roads close to the river is possible throughout today, Monday 27/12/2021. No flooding to properties is currently forecast. Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions.

We are constantly monitoring river levels and will update this message on Tuesday, 28/12/2021, or earlier if the situation changes.

items.message: This Flood Alert remains in force as river levels remain high and are expected to rise again in response to further rainfall which is forecast on Monday 27 December. Minor flooding could continue to affect low lying land and roads along the Rivers East Stour, Aylesford Stream, Whitewater Dyke, Ruckinge Dyke and the Great Stour upstream of Ashford town centre. Property flooding is not expected. We are monitoring the situation and our incident response staff have been out checking defences and structures throughout the area. The flood storage reservoir on the East Stour near Aldington is retaining some flood water to assist river drainage through Mersham and Ashford. This message will be updated by 8pm on Monday 27 December, or as the situation changes.

Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels continue to rise on the River Thame following recent rainfall, except in the Aylesbury area where levels are now dropping. Therefore, flooding of low-lying land, footpaths and roads is expected to continue, especially in the Thame area. 
River levels are high and slowly rising. A band of rain is forecast to move through the area this morning, 27/12/21, with the potential to be heavy at times. This will then clear leaving showers this afternoon and overnight. We expect river levels to remain high for the next few days with levels rising in Stadhampton and Dorchester as water moves downstream.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff will be in the area clearing weed/trash screens. 
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and avoid contact with flood water. 
This message will be updated this evening, 27/12/21, or as the situation changes.

This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.

Another 5 to 10mm of rain is forecast between 08:00 and 14:00 today (Monday 27/12/2021). River levels along the Western Rother are expected to rise again this afternoon, but should initially peak lower than seen on Sunday. Estimated peaks are 18:00 in Liss and Sheet, and 23:00 in Iping. Water levels are unlikely to peak in Lodsbridge near Selham until 09:00 Tuesday (28/12/2021), and Tuesday evening in Fittleworth. Minor flood impacts affecting fields, rural roads and gardens are expected. It is possible that river levels at Lodsbridge may peak a little higher than seen on Sunday. Uncertainty in the weather forecast means we are unsure if a second band of rain on Monday evening will occur. Additional rain would cause river levels to rise again and possibly higher than seen in recent days. Only small amounts of rain are forecast for the rest of the week. Please remain prepared as minor flood impacts will likely continue or return today, possibly along the length of the Western Rother. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 21:00 on 27/12/2021.

Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels are high on the Upper Wey as a result of heavy rainfall. Therefore, flooding of roads and farmland is possible in the Flash Bridge and Tilford areas. 
 We expect river levels to remain high.
We are closely monitoring the situation. 
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 
This message will be updated this evening, 27/12/21, or as the situation changes.

We expect river levels to remain high for the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Over the last several days we have seen heavy rainfall in the South Kesteven area. This means that the River Witham and associated tributaries have risen and remain high, which has led to flooding of low lying land and roads close to the river. Further rain is forecast over the next few days and we expect the river to remain high, but our forecasts indicate that flooding to properties isn't likely and therefore flood warnings are not expected to be issued. We are constantly monitoring river levels, and have staff in the field checking for blockages and clearing weedscreens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. Please do not attempt to drive through flood water. This message will be updated in the evening on Monday, 27th December, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Low lying roads between Harrold and Oakley in Bedfordshire
items.message:
River levels remain high at Turvey Sluice. as a result of recent rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible.  We expect flooding to affect roads close to the bridges at Harrold, Oakley, Felmersham and Radwell   
No further rainfall is forecast today.  We expect river levels to remain high for a few days. 
We are closely monitoring the situation. 
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated this evening, 27/12/21, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River East Glen, River West Glen, River Tham

items.message: Over the last several days we have seen heavy rainfall in the East and West Glens area. This means that the East and West Glens have risen and remain high, which has led to flooding of low lying land and roads close to the rivers. Further rain is forecast over the next few days and we expect the rivers to remain high, but our forecasts indicate that flooding to properties isn't likely and therefore flood warnings are not expected to be issued. We are constantly monitoring river levels, and have staff in the field checking for blockages and clearing weedscreens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. Please do not attempt to drive through flood water. This message will be updated in the evening on Monday, 27th December, or as the situation changes.

This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels are falling, but some standing water on low lying land and roads may remain. Monday 27/12/21 will be a largely dry day, with some showery rain. Further, more persistent rain is forecast on Wednesday 29/12/21, we will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.  
Our incident response staff are clearing debris from weed screens.  
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers which may be flooded and refer to local authority website for local road closures.

The risk of flooding from the River Ash has now reduced and levels have fallen below levels of concern. No further flooding to fields and roads is expected, however there may be standing water seen for several days.

Another 5 to 10mm of rain is forecast between 08:00 and 14:00 today (Monday 27/12/2021). River levels through Crowhurst are expected to rise again, and should peak at about 15:00 today at levels lower than seen on Sunday. However, it is possible a second band of rain on Monday evening could cause river levels to rise again. Minor flood impacts affecting fields, Crowhurst Recreation Ground, rural roads and gardens is expected on Monday afternoon. There is a possibility of flood water affecting properties on Forewood Lane and between the Plough Public House and the junction of Sampsons Lane on Sandrock Hill on Monday evening. Water will also affect Bexhill Road Recreation Ground in Bulverhythe. River levels should peak by 07:00 on Tuesday (28/12/2021), returning nearer to normal by Tuesday evening. Only small amounts of rain are currently forecast for the rest of the week. As a precaution, flood protection products are recommended to be installed in Crowhurst, if you have them. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 21:00 on 27/12/2021.

Another 5 to 10mm of rain is forecast between 08:00 and 14:00 today (Monday 27/12/2021). River levels through Hellingly are expected to rise again, but should initially peak a little lower than seen on Sunday at about 22:00 today. Minor flood impacts are expected affecting fields, roads such as Mill Lane in Hellingly, and gardens including near Station Road, Church Lane and Church Road, Hellingly. However, it is possible a second band of rain on Monday evening could cause river levels to rise again, and possibly at higher levels. In Alfriston, river levels are expected to rise higher than seen in recent days. From 05:00 on Tuesday (28/12/2021), flooding could possibly affect North Street, Willows Car Park, River Lane, The Old Clergy House and Deans Place Hotel, Alfriston. Only small amounts of rain are currently forecast for the rest of the week. Please plan to avoid driving through routes susceptible to flooding as described in this message at Hellingly and Alfriston. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 21:00 on 27/12/2021.

This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.  Further rainfall is possible over the next 12 hours.  
We continue to monitor the situation.  Our incident response staff are actively monitoring river levels and the weather forecast.

items.description: River Trent from Cromwell Weir to Gainsborough
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed.
River and high tide levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.
We continue to monitor the situation.

River levels remain high at the Brentingby Dam river gauge as a result of recent rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected to continue until at least this evening, 27/12/2021. Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Mill Lane and Water Lane at Frisby on the Wreake, Station Road at Thrussington, Broome Lane at Ratcliffe on the Wreake, Frisby, farmlands at Hoby, Brooksby, Thrussington, Ratcliffe and Syston. Further rainfall is expected over the next 24 hours. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated this afternoon, 27/012/2021, or as the situation changes

items.description: River Cherwell from Lower Heyford down to and including Oxford

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Cherwell, Woodeaton Brook, Bayswater Brook, Marston Brook, Peasmoor Brook

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels are rising on the Lower Cherwell following earlier heavy rainfall.  Therefore, flooding of low-lying land, footpaths and roads is expected overnight, especially in the Thrupp area. 
River levels are gradually rising and are forecast to come out of banks this morning, 27/12/2021. A band of rain is forecast to move through the area this morning, with the potential to be heavy at times. This will then clear leaving showers this afternoon and overnight. We expect river levels to remain high for the next few days.
We are closely monitoring the situation. 
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, many of which will be flooded at this point. 
This message will be updated this evening, 27/12/21, or as the situation changes.

items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message: River levels remain high on the River Brede after heavy rainfall over the Christmas weekend. Localised flooding of low lying land and roads is possible between Rye and Winchelsea between 3:30pm and 7:30pm on Monday 27 December, as higher river levels coincide with the next high tide. Flooding of properties is not expected. Further periods of heavy rainfall are forecast during Monday so we expect river levels to remain high until Tuesday, 28 December. We are closely monitoring the situation and our incident response staff have been checking our defences and structures throughout the area. Please avoid using low lying footpaths or roads near the watercourses during this time. This message will be updated by 8pm on Monday 27 December, or as the situation changes.

Overnight we have seen heavy rainfall in the River Ise and Alledge Brook area. This means that the River Ise and Alledge Brook have risen and remain high, which has led to flooding of low lying land and roads close to the river. Further rain is forecast over the next few days and we expect rivers to remain high, but our forecasts indicate that flooding to properties isn't likely and therefore flood warnings are not expected to be issued. We are constantly monitoring river levels, and have staff in the field checking for blockages and clearing weedscreens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. Please do not attempt to drive through flood water. This message will be updated in the evening on Monday, 27th December, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Rhee in Central Bedfordshire, Hertfordshire and Cambridgeshire
items.message:
River levels are rising at the Wimpole river gauge as a result of persistent rainfall over the past 48 hours.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible today, 27/12/21.  We expect flooding to affect River Rhee from Guilden Morden to Haslingfield   
No further rainfall is forecast today.  We expect river levels to remain high for a few days. 
We are closely monitoring the situation. 
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated this evening, 27/12/21, or as the situation changes.

The water level in the Eastern Yar is high and rising. Following this morning's rain, water will pond on low lying land near the river. Road and footpath flooding is expected. At Langbridge and Alverstone bridge, the river will be close to the top of the bank. Property flooding is not expected. Flooding of Golf Links Road and Moreton Common Road, Sandown will have been occurring today. Ditches near Fort Holiday Park will struggle to drain. At Alverstone, levels will rise until 23:00. At Sandown, levels will be high, peaking early Wednesday (29/12/2021). Further rain is forecast today and continues this week. During this time, levels will rise and fall. We are lowering the sluice at Bembridge to reduce levels at Brading Marshes during neap tides (when the river has limited opportunity to drain to sea) for the next 3 days. Water will pond on Brading Marshes. This will not affect property. We continue to monitor the forecast and clear any reported blockages. Please ensure any products used to protect from flooding are operating. We will update this message by 11:00 on 28/12/2021.
